features.text:
SOCIAL MOBILITY

The main target of the GTIF scenario is to assess how the correlation between mobility modalities and their evolution over time impact air pollution concentration and, directly, affect population health and contribute to climate change.
features.title: FWB1

features.text: Mobility modalities differently impact on concentration of various pollutants in the atmosphere (emissions per passenger per km, data from [https://doi.org/10.1016/j.eneco.2022.105941](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.eneco.2022.105941)).
features.title: Text1
features.__generatedText__: Mobility modalities differently impact on concentration of various pollutants in the atmosphere (emissions per passenger per km, data from https://doi.org/10.1016/j.eneco.2022.105941).

features.text: <--IMG-->https://race.esa.int/data/gtif/images/mobility_modality.png<--IMG-->
features.title: Image1

features.text: Unlike rural areas, where private motorised vehicles are still the most common transportation way, in urban areas (Vienna in the plot) there has been a clear evolution in the mobility modalities with a reduction of cars and increase of bikes and electric mobility (figures from Ajanovicet al. Electric Mobility in Cities: The Case of Vienna. [https://doi.org/10.3390/en14010217](https://doi.org/10.3390/en14010217)).
features.title: Text2
features.__generatedText__: Unlike rural areas, where private motorised vehicles are still the most common transportation way, in urban areas (Vienna in the plot) there has been a clear evolution in the mobility modalities with a reduction of cars and increase of bikes and electric mobility (figures from Ajanovicet al. Electric Mobility in Cities: The Case of Vienna. https://doi.org/10.3390/en14010217).

features.text:
There has been a clear evolution in car´s energy
source, with electric cars stating being used only
in the last 12 years

features.title: IMG3

features.text:
The number of electric vehicles has strongly
increased starting from 2010, with a contribution
of all different types, but with a fundamental
contribution provided by cars
features.title: Text4
features.__generatedText__: The number of electric vehicles has strongly increased starting from 2010, with a contribution of all different types, but with a fundamental contribution provided by cars

features.text: <--IMG-->https://race.esa.int/data/gtif/images/social_mobility_4.png<--IMG-->
features.title: IMG4

features.text:
Within this scenario we use:

* Mobility data. These data represent position / time of mobile devices with a very high accuracy. They can provide information to assess population density and identify different mobility modalities and trajectories. They can be used as proxy to estimate potential emissions.

* Model data allow simulating the pollution dynamics (ozone, nitrogen dioxide, particulate matter) outside direct measurement network (stations).

* Satellite data allow observing concentration of different pollutants (ozone, nitrogen dioxide, aerosol) over the whole country once per day. They are used to provide large scale measurements to complement models and verify mobility data.

The objective is to take advantage of the different
data sources to obtain a complete view of the dynamics of emission scenarios, and to have a quantitative tool to assess the improvement of air quality conditions carried by the increase of low impact mobility modalities (electric public and private vehicles, bikes) in near real time and for long time frames.
features.title: Text5
features.__generatedText__:
Within this scenario we use:

  • Mobility data. These data represent position / time of mobile devices with a very high accuracy. They can provide information to assess population density and identify different mobility modalities and trajectories. They can be used as proxy to estimate potential emissions.

  • Model data allow simulating the pollution dynamics (ozone, nitrogen dioxide, particulate matter) outside direct measurement network (stations).

  • Satellite data allow observing concentration of different pollutants (ozone, nitrogen dioxide, aerosol) over the whole country once per day. They are used to provide large scale measurements to complement models and verify mobility data.

The objective is to take advantage of the different data sources to obtain a complete view of the dynamics of emission scenarios, and to have a quantitative tool to assess the improvement of air quality conditions carried by the increase of low impact mobility modalities (electric public and private vehicles, bikes) in near real time and for long time frames.

features.text: <--IMG-->https://race.esa.int/data/gtif/images/social_mobility_5.png<--IMG-->
features.title: IMG5

features.text: Population presence information have been aggregated using the districts classification provided by Statistik Austria. Population presence patterns differ from working days to weekends. Assessing these changes allows monitoring and forecasting where and how pollution evolution dynamics.
features.title: FWB2
features.__generatedText__: Population presence information have been aggregated using the districts classification provided by Statistik Austria. Population presence patterns differ from working days to weekends. Assessing these changes allows monitoring and forecasting where and how pollution evolution dynamics.

features.title: IMG8

features.text:
Getting to the details for Vienna, the impact of mobility
modalities starts becoming relevant: in areas like the
Prater during weekend, despite high population
concentration, the pollution levels remain low, since most
of the persons present within the park are using low impact mobility means (metro, tram, e-scooter, bikes, walk) to reach the place.

features.title: Image 4.3

features.text:
The use of administrative boundaries to aggregate
data causes also some issues:
features.title: FWB4
features.__generatedText__: The use of administrative boundaries to aggregate data causes also some issues:

features.text:
The OMV Raffinerie Schwechat and the
Vienna international airport fall within the same
district. This causes that it is not possible to
correctly correlate pollution fluxes with mobility
modalities (including aircrafts) and industrial
activity.
features.title: Text 5.1
features.__generatedText__: The OMV Raffinerie Schwechat and the Vienna international airport fall within the same district. This causes that it is not possible to correctly correlate pollution fluxes with mobility modalities (including aircrafts) and industrial activity.

features.text: <--IMG-->https://race.esa.int/data/gtif/images/social_mobility_8.png<--IMG-->
features.title: Image 5.1

features.text: The plot shows that mobility data at their highest resolution allow discriminating between industrial plant and airport presence.
features.title: Text 5.2
features.__generatedText__: The plot shows that mobility data at their highest resolution allow discriminating between industrial plant and airport presence.

features.text: <--IMG-->https://race.esa.int/data/gtif/images/social_mobility_9.png<--IMG-->
features.title: Image 5.2

features.text: The 24-hour time evolution of population presence over the Inner Prater, the OMV Raffinerie and the Vienna International airport shows the different patterns that are masked out by the district aggregation.
features.title: Text 5.3/5.4
features.__generatedText__: The 24-hour time evolution of population presence over the Inner Prater, the OMV Raffinerie and the Vienna International airport shows the different patterns that are masked out by the district aggregation.

features.text:
Besides population presence, the length and duration of
movements allow a macro-classification of the mobility
modalities at national level.

features.text: The video shows the trajectories over the whole Austria (overview) for a typical July day.
features.title: Text 6.1
features.__generatedText__: The video shows the trajectories over the whole Austria (overview) for a typical July day.

features.text: <--VID-->https://eox-gtif-public.s3.eu-central-1.amazonaws.com/videos/sistema/Demo_Austria_trajectories.mp4<--VID-->
features.title: Video 6.1

features.text:
In order to assess how road traffic impacts on pollution,
and to check whether working days and weekend /
holiday fluxes contribute differently to the overall
pollution, the Inn valley and the Innsbruck intersection
toward Brennerpass have been monitored.
features.title: FWB7
features.__generatedText__: In order to assess how road traffic impacts on pollution, and to check whether working days and weekend / holiday fluxes contribute differently to the overall pollution, the Inn valley and the Innsbruck intersection toward Brennerpass have been monitored.

features.text: The split window video focuses on the area around Innsbruck showing mobility trajectories during working days(left) and weekend (right) typical 24h loops for July 2021. The patterns are quite different at the beginning of the day, as well as for the trends. The vehicles compositions shall also be different (trucks versus cars) but this might be assessed at second stage of the project.
